fields.descriptive_line: Silver with kingwood details, London hallmarks for 1933-4, mark of H.G. Murphy and the Falcon mark for Murphy's workshop.

fields.name: At the Sign of the Falcon. H.G.Murphy, Art Deco Jeweller and Silversmith

fields.physical_description:
[Sugar bowl] Sugar basin with kingwood handles, part of a tea service.  The body of the vessel is formed as a circular drum from two die stamped circular halves, joined by a folded over seam, internally.  Each side panel is embellished with three concentric mouldings.  The bottom edge of the handles stabilise the vessel.  The basin is additionally stabised by two narrow strips od silver soldered across the body at the base.  The handles, on either side of the central drum, are of kingwood, square in cross section and curved to the same radius as the vessel.  They are attached to the body by a flat strip of silver at either end in the form of a T shaped section and secured by a pin.  The opposite end of the connecting strip is perpendicular to the curved wall.
[Lid (from a tea service)] The lid is a curved strip of silver which follows the radius of the body.  It is retained by an internal flange.  The kingwood knop is an inverted triangle, attached to the lid by a pin through its centre and retained on the underside of the lid by a circular, threaded nut.
fields.dimensions:
[Sugar bowl] Height: 11.5 cm, Length: 17 cm, Width: 6 cm
[Lid (from a tea service)] Height: 4.4 cm, Length: 7.4 cm, Width: 4.7 cm
fields.marks:
[Sugar bowl] Mark of HGM for H.G. Murphy, stamped on the underside of the base.
[Sugar bowl] London hallmarks for 1933-4, stamped on the underside of the base.
[Sugar bowl] Falcon mark for Murphy's workshop, stamped on the bottom bracket for one of the handles.
[Lid (from a tea service)] Mark of HGM for H.G. Murphy, stamped on the side flange.
[Lid (from a tea service)] London hallmarks for 1933-4, stamped on the side flange.
[Lid (from a tea service)] The lion passant and leopard's head only, stamped on the finial.
fields.public_access_description:
H. G. Murphy (1884-1939) was a pupil of Henry Wilson at the Central School of Arts and Crafts and then studied briefly under Emil Lettré in Berlin.  In 1913 he established his own workshop in London.  From 1907, alongside running his own workshop, he taught at the Royal College of Art and later at the Central School.  He was the first silversmith to be appointed Principal of the Central School.

This service was published in Design for Today Vol.II, p.300, (London 1934) with the following commentary:

DESIGN IN SILVER

The exhibition of English silversmiths' work at the Victoria and Albert Museum arranged by the Museum Authorities and the Council for Art and Industry, traces the development of design as shown in silver by examples of ancient and modern side by side.  The modern examples, with some exceptions, are of traditional form shorn of embellishement.  Here and there the designer has wavered, adding a little beading along the rim or a little engraving.

We illustrate a tea set designed by H.G. Murphy, of 58 Weymouth Street, which won the highest award at the Milan Exhibition of 1933.  The design may at first sight seem deliberately eccentric, but its shape is in fact dictated by the method of machine manufacture.  It cost £20, which we understand is much less than a corresponding set manufactured by old methods would cost.  The lids lift off completely thus dispensing with hinges which must be hand-made.  The hand can be inserted for cleaning.  The handles are in kingwood.
fields.exhibition_history: At the Sign of the Falcon. H.G.Murphy, Art Deco Jeweller and Silversmith (The Goldsmiths' Company, Goldsmiths' Hall 04/04/2005-20/04/2005)
fields.credit: Given by Andrew Cox in memory of his parents, Mr and Mrs John Cox.
